content.description:
Weeperhorn is the little mountain, the problem climbs a great looking piece of chocolate sandstone over a perfect landing.

Sit start with a left hand pinch and a right wherever is most comfortable.  From there, make a move out right to the crimp, buckle the heel, fall into the left hand sidepull, bump up to the right hand crimp, match a left heel on the sidepull, crank up, and hit the huge shelf out right. Make a few other easy moves, and top it out.

The move to the shelf is likely the crux.  Deciding what to use with the left hand is the key.  There are options, so go with what feels good.
content.protection: A few pads, the landing is spectacular though.
content.location: This is on the South face of Weeperhorn Boulder.

content.description: Stand start with hands matched on the jug about five feet off the ground.  From there, work up to the shelf, get a foot up high and reach to the solid lip for an easy topout.
content.protection: A pad or two. The landing is good, but there is a large rock directly behind the problem.
content.location: This is on the West face of Weeperhorn Boulder.

content.description:
Kentucky Six climbs around an overhanging arete onto a vertical face via some tricky footwork and a fair amount of balance.

Sit start with a left hand sidepull and a right hand sloper edge on the arete. From there, pull up, bump the right hand to a two-finger edge, cross over with the right to a gaston edge, place a tenuous left heel hook, reach a sloper edge with the left hand, pull up and reach the shelf, then traverse to the shelf out left, throw a high toe and top it out.
content.protection: A pair of pads will work fine. The landing is actually very good.
content.location: It climbs the west face of Weeperhorn.

content.description: Stand start with a left hand edge and a left foot edge. From there, pop off the ground with a right foot to an edge rail, work the thin feet up high, reach the lip and top it out using the good bumps.
content.protection: A pair of pads. The landing has a pair of rocks that can be covered with the correct pad placement.
content.location: It climbs the far northern section of Weeperhorn's west facing vertical/slab face.
